name: Tatian

locations.description: Studied in Rome, later returned to Syria

summary: Tatian was an Assyrian Christian writer and theologian of the 2nd century. He was a pupil of Justin Martyr in Rome and later returned to Syria. He is best known for creating the Diatessaron, a harmony of the four Gospels that became the standard Gospel text in the Syriac-speaking churches until the 5th century. He later became associated with the Encratite heresy, which rejected marriage and the consumption of meat and wine.
